summary_points.title: Markets Poised for a Moderately Higher Open
summary_points.summary: The Sensex and Nifty 50 are expected to open marginally higher amid cautious investor sentiment and mixed global market cues. Gift Nifty trading around the 24,670 level—nearly a 20-point premium to the previous Nifty futures close—points to a mildly positive start, though traders remain wary ahead of further tariff developments.

summary_points.title: Global Cues Paint a Mixed Picture
summary_points.summary: Asian markets traded mostly lower, with Japan’s Nikkei down 0.33% and South Korea’s Kospi off 0.19%, while Hong Kong futures suggested a higher open. In contrast, US indices closed at record highs—S&P 500 up 0.32%, Dow Jones up 0.16% and Nasdaq up 0.53%—providing some relief to domestic investors.

summary_points.title: Steep Losses on US Tariff Concerns
summary_points.summary: On Thursday, Indian equities saw a sharp sell-off after the US imposed 50% tariffs on Indian goods. The Sensex tumbled 705.97 points (0.87%) to 80,080.57, while the Nifty 50 fell 211.15 points (0.85%) to 24,500.90, marking one of the largest single-day declines in recent sessions.

summary_points.title: Bearish Technical Indicators Dominate Charts
summary_points.summary: Technical charts are signalling continued weakness: the Sensex formed a bearish daily candle and shows a lower top formation intraday. The Nifty breached its 100-day moving average and extended its negative bias, suggesting further downside unless relief measures or negotiations are announced.

summary_points.title: Top Stock Picks to Watch Today
summary_points.summary: Marketsmith India recommends buying Jindal Stainless at ₹806 with a target price of ₹930 and a stop loss at ₹750. The stock trades above key moving averages with positive momentum, though investors should note its high ESG risk rating, cyclical volatility and trade-related headwinds.

summary_points.title: Key Drivers Behind the Recent Market Crash
summary_points.summary: Four main factors drove Thursday’s 706-point plunge in the Sensex: newly imposed US tariffs on Indian exports, foreign fund outflows, weak global cues and bearish technical setups. The rout erased ₹4.67 lakh crore in BSE market value, highlighting the depth of investor concerns.

market_drivers.summary: Today’s market downturn was primarily driven by fresh U.S. tariffs of 25% on Indian exports, which dampened exporter sentiment and triggered foreign institutional outflows against a backdrop of weak global cues after mixed Asian trading and record closes on Wall Street. Domestic technicals reinforced the bearish tone as the Nifty slipped below its key moving averages, while company-specific news—such as a discounted stake sale by an IndiGo co-founder weighing on InterGlobe Aviation and a rally in Ola Electric after its Gen-3 scooters secured certification—added to the volatility. Hopes for near-term policy support from upcoming GST reforms and other government measures offered only limited relief, leaving headline indices under sustained pressure.
